0.text:
Translator: Donatella Gagliano
Reviewer: Denise RQ

11.text: I'm here to share with you

13.text:
two really important things
that I've learnt so far

16.text:
in how to change the game
before it changes you.

22.text: One of them is a way of being,

25.text:
the other is just
such a simple tool that I learnt.

29.text:
The way of being is this
- Sorry, mother -

38.text: in essence, this means to be courageous.

42.text:
It means to have tenacity, it means
to have a huge amount of resilience.

48.text:
It's the thousand things that go wrong
before the one that goes right.

54.text:
I've been really lucky to bring
this philosophy, this way of existing

58.text: to a thing that I really love:

63.text:
The way that I exist in sports technology
is to look at the human being as a species

69.text:
where there are two things that really
differentiate us from all other species:

75.text:
it's making fire,
and it's clothing ourselves.

80.text:
I work in the clothing ourselves bit,
so job security is pretty damn good.

88.text:
And in working at this interface,
between the human and clothing technology

93.text:
I have seen
some really amazing things happen.

96.text:
I've seen that technology
can be the difference

104.text:
human potential can get
to the highest possible levels,

107.text:
and human performance can do things
that we never realized would be possible.

114.text:
It's been really a pleasure to work
with athletes all over the world

118.text: to change the shapes of their bodies

120.text:
as they move more effortlessly
through the water

123.text:
to make them feel lighter,
tighter, brighter.

128.text:
I've been lucky enough to have
products on the backs of athletes

132.text:
of some of the most competitive
leagues on the planet;

137.text:
world championships, Olympics,
world records have been broken,

144.text: So I've seen what technology can do.

148.text:
I've also seen
what technology can do to a family

152.text:
I grew up in a world
where obviously my father was my hero.

158.text: And I've seen that with technology

163.text:
growing and changing
at the rate that it does,

169.text: So my father, who was my hero,

172.text: an endurance athlete, a triathlon pioneer,

174.text:
[was also] one of the last
human versions of Photoshop.

178.text:
He worked in a laboratory where they'd use
chemicals, photographic techniques,

185.text:
a scalpel to sculpture a model's thigh
to create the images that you would see

191.text:
in printed press
for the advertising industry.

195.text:
The digital revolution took hold,
I hadn't even send my first email by then.

201.text:
This industry evaporated overnight,
and I realized in that moment

206.text:
that there are three people
or three kinds of people in the world.

212.text:
There are people that when things
like that happen, they perish.

217.text:
There are people when things
like that happen,

220.text:
they pivot and adapt
just like my parents did.

225.text:
And then there are the people
that create those shifts in the world.

230.text:
I made a declaration,
right then and there

233.text: that I would create shifts in the world.

237.text:
That's what I've been doing ever since
living under these words.

243.text:
Yet, a really interesting thing
started to happen.

251.text:
those marginal gains you were so convinced
that you're going to achieve

255.text: didn't get the results you would expect.

261.text:
Something else was happening,
it's human will.

265.text:
You all heard of the old adage
of "where there's a will, there's a way".

272.text:
But breaking habits, encouraging
people to smash their paradigms

279.text:
because also, where there is a will,
there is no way.

282.text:
I've seen many raised eyebrows,
"Are you sure?", "I don't think so,"

290.text:
You realize that being in somewhat
of a technical arms race

296.text: is no way you see success.

302.text:
where, after five years
and millions of dollars

305.text:
you have this wonderful,
beautiful technology

307.text: that you know it could change the world;

310.text:
you walk gingerly to the edge
of the commercial part of the company

315.text: where there is that imaginary wall.

318.text:
You throw it over the wall,
listen for the cheers,

321.text:
now, you'll hear people running away
like you just dropped the proverbial bomb.

328.text:
So again, something else has to happen,
and I figured you can get away with it.

332.text: I'm British so I can be charming.

340.text:
You could be diplomatic
as a competitor within,

342.text: but something still needed to be done.

345.text: You can't just be a good storyteller,

347.text:
you have to have stories
that really mean something.

350.text:
And that brought me to the tool,
such a simple tool.

357.text: I discovered this several years ago.

360.text:
It is Roberto Verganti's tool
for technical epiphany.

364.text:
For me, it represents
the beautiful relationship

375.text:
I realized I spent
most of my existence in technology,

380.text:
in the technical arms race
trying to be better and better

385.text: and realizing I was also being critical

387.text:
of other technologies
that were just better.

391.text:
I look at a lot of wearable technology
that fills our drawers and desks.

396.text:
The world is not defined
by steps and calories

399.text:
just like the scales in our bathroom
don't make us thin.

407.text:
Then meaning: there is some incredible,
inspirational products in this space

413.text:
where true artistic expression
has created those changes.

419.text:
Products like the stiletto;
I still don't understand the stiletto.

424.text:
A rational engineer would never build
the stiletto, yet it exists.

432.text: This is where, if you get this wrong,

435.text:
because you can see them going
in two completely different directions

444.text:
for selling rainbows
where there's perhaps not a pot of gold.

454.text:
where technology enables
a new meaning in the world.

459.text:
Because with new meanings,
you create new perspectives,

462.text:
and people start to perceive
the world differently.

467.text:
When you perceive the world differently,
because perception is reality,

470.text: what you feel is what you believe,

473.text:
the behavior starts to change,
the movement starts to shift.

477.text:
There are some really wonderful examples
that are set up here,

480.text:
some of you, I'm sure,
you're very familiar with.

484.text:
There was a race for some time
up and down this vertical axis

487.text:
between Sony, Microsoft,
Xbox, and PlayStation,

501.text:
a technical arms race,
and it's always ending stalemate.

508.text: They find motion sensing, a technology.

514.text: They look at gaming and realize

516.text:
that people don't just want
to have mega-thumbs,

519.text:
they want
a physically immersive experience.

522.text:
So they bring these two things together --
a technical epiphany.

526.text:
Apple do that all the time
with desktop computing, smartphones,

532.text:
tablets, shifts in the world
that create behavior change.

540.text:
Knowing this and doing this
are two very different things;

546.text:
that's why I come back to this:
'Illegitimi non carborundum.'

552.text:
which by the way,
the literal translation is,

555.text: "Don't let the bastards grind you down."

560.text:
Because the world of technology
will continue to develop

566.text: The world will evolve, it's nature's way.

571.text: We mutate, we populate, we move on.

575.text:
The game is always going to change,
so you have a choice.

580.text:
Be the change, enable shifts,
and don't let the bastards grind you down.
